content: The report summarizes the USDA's efforts to establish a national animal traceability system for rapid disease outbreak response. Despite economic benefits, federal proposals face controversy in the U.S. cattle industry. The report discusses background on animal ID and traceability, reviews arguments for and against a national system, and highlights unresolved issues. Appendices provide a timeline of the U.S. National Animal Identification System and information on international organizations involved in animal health standards. The USDA announced a new approach to animal disease traceability, replacing the National Animal Identification System. States and tribal nations can choose their own level of animal ID and traceability. All animals moving in interstate commerce must have traceable ID back to their originating state. The USDA established a Traceability Regulation Working Group with state, tribal nation, and APHIS officials to develop a proposed rule for animal disease traceability. Public meetings were held to gather feedback on the framework, and USDA released publications outlining their recommendations in August 2010. The USDA's traceability framework for animal disease management is still evolving, with states and tribal nations being responsible for implementing within-state programs. These programs may include existing ID systems or more detailed birth-to-market ID systems. Federal rules will only apply to livestock moving interstate, with data collection and storage handled by state authorities, not the federal government. The federal rules for livestock traceability will apply to animals moving interstate, requiring official identification and an Interstate Certificate of Veterinary Inspection (ICVI). Exemptions will be defined in the rules, with acceptable identification types outlined in federal regulations. Each state and tribal nation will be evaluated based on performance standards defined through rulemaking, with detailed traceability cooperative agreements with APHIS. Federal funding availability will support the implementation of the traceability framework. The federal rules for livestock traceability will apply to animals moving interstate, requiring official identification and an Interstate Certificate of Veterinary Inspection (ICVI). Each state and tribal nation will have detailed traceability cooperative agreements with APHIS. Federal funding for animal traceability is not designated in the FY2011 agriculture appropriations bill, but funding could be considered after needs are identified. The program governing animal disease traceability of interstate animal movements will be implemented through federal regulations. USDA will define animal disease traceability with a new section in Title 9 of the Code of Federal Regulations, and a proposed rule could be published in April 2011. Major outbreaks of harmful animal diseases like avian influenza, foot and mouth disease, and mad cow disease have caused significant economic damages. The United States has been fortunate in avoiding catastrophic disease outbreaks, but the potential economic consequences of a foot and mouth disease outbreak could be staggering, costing the U.S. cattle industry billions of dollars. The economic impact of major animal disease outbreaks in the 1990s and early 2000s led to the development of animal identification and traceability systems in various countries. These programs vary from voluntary in the United States to mandatory in the EU, Japan, and South Korea. Some major importers like Japan and South Korea are considering requiring traceability on imported meat products, which could impact market access and have significant economic implications. The United States is a major producer and exporter of livestock and animal products, leading in beef and poultry production. It is also a top exporter of pork and beef, while being the leading importer of beef. Animal identification (ID) is crucial for tracking animals from birth to market. U.S. exports of animal products account for a significant portion of domestic production. Animal identification (ID) is essential for tracking farm animals from birth through the marketing chain. It includes information on the animal's origins and traceability to quickly respond to disease outbreaks or tainted food, minimizing threats to human and animal health. Different countries have variations in their animal ID systems, but the ideal system involves a national database accessible via a high-speed computer network. Animal ID systems track information from birth to slaughter, including details like owner, movements, and slaughter location. Reasons for tracking include rapid response to health concerns and verifying premium production processes. In the US, focus is on animal health, while other countries like the EU prioritize both health and food safety. In countries like the EU, Japan, and South Korea, animal ID systems focus on both animal health and food safety, with comprehensive traceability systems extending to the retail consumer. International buyers are demanding more information on the history of animal products, leading to the need for traceability systems. Proponents argue that a national animal ID system enhances animal health surveillance and disease eradication. A national animal ID and traceability system can enhance animal health surveillance and disease eradication by facilitating early detection of disease outbreaks and minimizing the economic impact of outbreaks through compartmentalization. This system would reduce disease testing costs for producers and limit the spread of harmful diseases, ultimately benefiting regional and national levels. Compartmentalization helps reduce economic damage from disease outbreaks and re-establish international market access. These programs also include traceability measures like the national organic certification program and mandatory country-of-origin labeling. Traceability programs offer valuable management tools for producers by providing post-mortem information on production techniques and success factors. An animal ID and traceability program would help producers track performance history, increase transparency in the supply chain, maintain records on animal movements and health, and address food safety and national security concerns. This program collaborates with federal and state food safety agencies to protect the food supply from threats to human health and foodborne illnesses. An animal ID system could enhance animal welfare in response to natural disasters, but opponents argue it constitutes an invasion of privacy and increases costs and technical complexity. Critics argue that implementing a national animal identification system could lead to increased costs and technical complexity, with the majority of the financial burden falling on the cattle sector. Additionally, the system may favor vertical integration over family farms, as individual animals would need to be tagged, unlike in the pork and poultry industries where animals are raised and moved in lots. Implementing a national animal identification system could disadvantage cattle producers due to added costs and lack of market power. A study by APHIS in 2009 evaluated the economic benefits and costs of implementing NAIS, with input from economists at various universities. The report by researchers from various universities estimated the costs of implementing NAIS across multiple species with varying participation rates. The study assumed individual ID tagging for cattle, group ID tagging for swine (except for breeding animals), and unique group ID tagging for poultry. The estimated annual costs for full pre-harvest traceability with 100% participation were around $228 million for livestock industries, increasing to $304.2 million when horses were included. The majority of costs were associated with the cattle sector, at $5.97 per animal marketed. The study estimated that identification tags and tagging for cattle accounted for 75% of the cattle sector's annual adoption costs, ranging from $3.30 to $5.22 per animal. In comparison, other livestock sectors had lower costs per animal: $0.059 per swine, $1.39 per sheep, $0.0007 per broiler, $0.002 per turkey, and $0.0195 per layer. The economic benefits of NAIS with full participation outweighed the costs, including savings in disease control programs, quicker market recovery after outbreaks, and potential access to international markets. The study found that the implementation of NAIS could bring economic benefits such as re-establishing markets quickly after disease outbreaks, expanded market access, and increased consumer demand.
